changes-in-the-branch-lengths-binning.text: Changes in the branch lengths binning

pageProps.body:
Branch Lengths

Changes in the branch lengths binning

Previously we had that the total sum of the branch length was equal to 1. Now we have changed the binning so that the average branch length is equal to 1.

We define mmm as the middle point of each bin so that we have m0m_0m0​ the middle point of bin 000. Now, the branch length of one has to be a middle point of the bins. We have as lower bound 0, and we want as many bins on the right side as on the left side of 111.

For example, if we have 7 bins, we want to have 3.5 bins on the right side of 1 and 3.5 on the left side. We define KKK as the number of bins on one side of 1 i.e. 3.5. δ\deltaδ which is the interval of each bin is thus equal to

δ=1K+12=22K+1\delta = \frac{1}{K+\frac{1}{2}} = \frac{2}{2K+1}δ=K+21​1​=2K+12​

if K=N2K=\frac{N}{2}K=2N​ and NNN is the total number of bins we can simplify to

δ=2N+1\delta = \frac{2}{N+1}δ=N+12​

For each bin iii where i=(0,...,N−1)i = (0, ..., N-1)i=(0,...,N−1) the middle point mim_imi​, the lower bound lil_ili​ and the upper bound uiu_iui​ are equal to

mi=δ(i+12)li=δiui=δ(i+1)\begin{align} m_i &= \delta (i + \frac{1}{2}) \\ l_i &= \delta i \\ u_i &= \delta (i+1)\\ \end{align}mi​li​ui​​=δ(i+21​)=δi=δ(i+1)​​

Formulation

As previously, let us define NNN the total number of bins and BBB the total number of branch length in the tree. We want to constrain the tree in order to have an average branch length in the tree of 1.

We thus have

1B∑b=0B−1mi(b)=1\frac{1}{B} \sum_{b=0}^{B-1}{m_{i_{(b)}}} = 1B1​b=0∑B−1​mi(b)​​=1

As defined before, mi=δ(i+12)m_i = \delta (i + \frac{1}{2})mi​=δ(i+21​) and δ=2N+1\delta = \frac{2}{N+1}δ=N+12​ so we have

1=1B∑bδ(ib+12)B=∑bδ(ib+12)B=2N+1∑b(ib+12)BN+12=∑bib+B2B(N+12−12)=∑bibBN2=∑bib\begin{align} 1 &= \frac{1}{B}\sum_b \delta(i_{b} + \frac{1}{2}) \\ B &= \sum_b \delta (i_b + \frac{1}{2}) \\ B &= \frac{2}{N+1} \sum_b (i_b+\frac{1}{2}) \\ B \frac{N+1}{2} &= \sum_b i_b + \frac{B}{2} \\ B (\frac{N+1}{2} - \frac{1}{2}) &= \sum_b i_b \\ \frac{BN}{2} &= \sum_b i_b \end{align}1BBB2N+1​B(2N+1​−21​)2BN​​=B1​b∑​δ(ib​+21​)=b∑​δ(ib​+21​)=N+12​b∑​(ib​+21​)=b∑​ib​+2B​=b∑​ib​=b∑​ib​​​

Example

If we have N=100N=100N=100 and B=50B=50B=50, and let us set all branches to a length of 1 (in order to have an average of 1). Then the index of the bin where the branch length is one, is at 50. We thus have 50⋅1002=2500\frac{50 \cdot 100}{2} = 2500250⋅100​=2500 and we have 505050 branches with a bin index of 505050 which is also equal to 250025002500.

noteIndex.title: Anticipated Chemistry of Life

welcome-to-the-dendron-of-the-anticipate.text: Welcome to the Dendron of the Anticipated Chemistry of Life

noteIndex.body:
# Welcome to the Dendron of the Anticipated Chemistry of Life

This dendron has the purpose to serve as a laboratory notebook for my PhD thesis. It will contain all the notes that I will take during my research as well as some results of the experiments and models that I will develop and test.

github.editLinkText: Feel free to participate and click here to edit this page on Github !
